name: CheckIn
text message: Have you been able to use consequences for not following instructions or forgetting household rules with your child or teen? How has it been?

name: CheckIn
text message: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

name: CheckIn
text message: Wonderful! When you are able to stay calm, give your child a choice to follow an instruction, and follow through with fair a consequence, you teach your child responsibilities for their actions. Keep it up!

name: CheckIn
text message: Sorry you did not manage well. This can be really difficult so be patient with yourself.

name: CheckIn
text message: What was difficult about using consequences?
option 1: I got very angry with my child or teen and yelled at them
option 2: I forgot to give my child or teen a choice to comply before giving the consequence
option 3: My child or teen got very angry with me after I gave the consequence
option 4: My child or teen complained that the consequence was not fair
option 5: I forgot to follow through with the consequence
option 6: I am giving too many consequences all the time

name: CheckIn
text message: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

name: CheckIn
text message: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.

name: CheckIn
text message: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!

name: CheckIn
text message: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.

name: CheckIn
text message: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!

name: CheckIn
text message: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.

name: CheckIn
text message: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!
